titleStmt.title: Chaos and hyperchaos in fractional-order cellular neural networks $

analytic.title: Chaos and hyperchaos in fractional-order cellular neural networks $

biblStruct.note: Received 15 June 2011 Received in revised form 24 October 2011 Accepted 7 January 2012 Communicated by H. Jiang

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Hyperchaos Fractional-order Cellular neural network Lyapunov exponents Poincare ´section Bifurcation diagram

div.p: In this paper, a fractional-order four-cell cellular neural network is proposed and the complex dynamical behaviors of such a network are investigated by means of numerical simulations. Several varieties of interesting dynamical behaviors, such as periodic, chaotic and hyperchaotic motions, are displayed. In addition, it can be found that the network does exhibit hyperchaotic phenomena over a wide range of values of some specified parameter. The existence of chaotic and hyperchaotic attractors is verified with the related Lyapunov exponent spectrum, bifurcation diagram and phase portraits. Meanwhile, the Lyapunov exponents and Poincare ´sections are calculated for some typical parameters, respectively.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Hyperchaos, which is defined as a chaotic attractor with more than one positive Lyapunov exponents, was firstly reported by R össler in 1979 [1]. Compared with chaotic attractor, it displays much richer dynamical behaviors, and therefore is considered as a powerful tool in secure communication for its capability of improving the security of chaotic communication systems [2]. During the past few decades, a considerable amount of research has been devoted to the development of efficient methods and techniques for the generation and circuit implementation of hyperchaos [3][4][5]. However, as we all know, one of the necessary conditions which ensure the existence of hyperchaotic attractors is that the minimal dimension of the phase space of an autonomous system is at least four. Evidently, if one wants to generate a more complicated hyperchaos (i.e., a hyperchaotic attractor with more than two positive Lyapunov exponents), it is unavoidable to increase the dimension of the autonomous system and this restricts the applications of the developed hyperchaotic system.

Fractional calculus, which deals with derivatives and integrals of arbitrary order, was firstly introduced 300 years ago. However, it is only in recent decades that fractional calculus is applied to physics, applied mathematics and engineering [6][7][8]. Fractional-order models have been proven to be an excellent instrument for the description of memory and hereditary properties of various materials and processes in comparison with classical integer-order models [6][7][8]. Nowadays, study on the complex dynamical behaviors of fractional-order systems, including chaos and hyperchaos, has become a very hot research topic. Compared with integer-order chaotic systems, fractional-order chaotic systems show higher nonlinearity and more degrees of freedom in the models due to the existence of the fractional derivatives. Moreover, the derivative orders can be used as secret keys as well [9]. It has been found that hyperchaotic behavior of an integer-order nonlinear system is preserved when the order becomes fractional [10]. Obviously, this allows us to generate a fractional-order hyperchaotic system from its integer-order counterpart without changing the numbers of the system equations. For instance, in [11], it is shown that the fractional-order R össler hyperchaotic equation can still behave in a hyperchaotic manner with order as low as 3.8. In [12], the lowest fractional order for the hyperchaotic system to yield hyperchaos is approximately 3.7. In [13], a fractional-order hyperchaotic system with order 3.8 is proposed. In [14], the lowest order for the proposed system to generate hyperchaos is determined as 2.88.

Cellular neural networks (CNNs) have been extensively investigated both in theory and applications since it was proposed by Chua and Yang in [15,16]. It has been demonstrated that the classical integer-order CNNs can exhibit quite rich dynamical behaviors. For instance, bifurcation phenomena and chaotic behaviors for CNNs with or without delay are investigated in [17,18]. Hyperchaotic behaviors in CNNs or Hopfield-type neural networks are displayed in [19,20]. In [21], a new four-dimensional CNN is designed, which can generate complex dynamics, including periodic solutions, chaos and hyperchaos. Furthermore, efforts have been made to study the complex dynamics of fractional-order cellular neural networks in recent years. In [22], Arena et al. firstly introduced a new class of CNN with fractional order cells. In [23], Petra ´š presented a fractional three-cell CNN which exhibits limit cycle and stable orbit for different values of parameters and the total order of such a system is 2.7. A fractional two-cell chaotic CNN was reported in [24] and the corresponding strange attractor was shown. It is worth noting that in view of the significance of fractional-order CNNs and the approximation methods, we refer the readers to [23] and references cited therein for more details.

However, to the best of our knowledge, there is no effort being made in the literature to study the hyperchaotic dynamics of fractional-order CNNs so far. Motivated by the above-mentioned reasons, we introduce fractional derivative to the four-cell CNN proposed in [21] and present a new fractional-order CNN system. The main aim of this paper is to investigate the hyperchaotic phenomena in the newly proposed fractional-order CNN, which may provide potential applications in secure communication. As will be shown below, when the parameters of the network are fixed, the lowest order for chaos to exist is determined. Moreover, hyperchaotic attractors are found within a certain range of some specified parameter. Besides, the existence of chaos and hyperchaos is verified with Lyapunov exponent spectrum, bifurcation diagram, Poincare ´sections, and phase portraits, respectively.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows: in Section 2, basic definition in fractional calculus and a lemma to testify the stability of fractional-order linear systems are presented. In Section 3, the fractional-order four-cell CNN is proposed and the lowest order for chaos to exist is determined. Bifurcation analysis is made in Section 4 and the ranges of the specified parameter are determined for different dynamical behaviors, respectively. Finally, some concluding remarks are reported in Section 5.

div.head: Basic definition and preliminaries
div.p: There are three most frequently used definitions for fractional derivatives [6], that is, Riemann-Liouville, Gr ünwald-Letnikov and Caputo definitions. In pure mathematics, Riemann-Liouville derivative is more commonly used than Caputo derivative. However, the main advantage of Caputo definition is that the initial conditions for fractional-order differential equations with Caputo derivatives take on the same form as for integer-order differential equations [6]. And therefore, Caputo definition is used in this paper.
Definition 1 (Podlubny [6]). The Caputo fractional derivative of order a of a continuous function f : R þ -R is defined as follows: where G is G-function, and
div.formula: D a t f ðtÞ ¼ 1 GðnÀaÞ R t 0 f ðnÞðtÞ
ðtÀtÞ a þ 1Àn dt, nÀ1 oa o n, d n dt n f ðtÞ, a ¼ n, 8 > > > > < > > > > :
GðzÞ ¼ Z 1 0 e Àt t
div.p: In this case, each component of the states decays toward 0 like t Àa . Also, this system is stable if and only if 9argðeigðAÞÞ9 Z ap=2 and those critical eigenvalues that satisfy 9argðeigðAÞÞ9 ¼ ap=2 have geometric multiplicity one.

div.head: Introduction of the fractional-order CNN
div.p: In [21], a four-dimensional CNN was reported, which can exhibit complex dynamical behaviors such as period, chaos and hyperchaos. The dynamics of such a network can be described as follows:
div.formula: _ x 1 ðtÞ ¼ Àx 3 Àx 4 , _ x 2 ðtÞ ¼ 2x 2 þ x 3 , _ x 3 ðtÞ ¼ 14x 1 À14x 2 , _ x 4 ðtÞ ¼ 100ðx 1 Àgðx 4 ÞþwÞ,ð2Þ
div.p: where
div.formula: gðx 4 Þ ¼ ax 4 Àð9x 4 À0:49À9x 4 À0:89À9x 4 þ0:49þ 9x 4 þ 0:89Þ:
div.p: In [21], when fixing a ¼ 1 and varying w or fixing w¼0 and varying a, some typical parameter values for w or a to generate chaos and hyperchaos are determined. In particular, when a ¼ 1 and w ¼0, the phase portraits of the hyperchaotic attractor of system (2) are shown in Fig. 1.
In this paper, we generalize system (2) to fractional-order case and propose the fractional-order four-cell CNN as follows:
div.formula: D a t x 1 ðtÞ ¼ Àx 3 Àx 4 , D a t x 2 ðtÞ ¼ 2x 2 þ x 3 , D a t x 3 ðtÞ ¼ 14x 1 À14x 2 , D a t x 4 ðtÞ ¼ 100ðx 1 Àgðx 4 ÞÞ,ð3Þ
div.p: where
div.formula: gðx 4 Þ ¼ x 4 Àð9x 4 À0:49À9x 4 À0:89À9x 4 þ 0:49 þ 9x 4 þ 0:89Þ:
div.p: In this section, the complex dynamics of the fractional-order CNN ( 3) is discussed and the lowest order for chaos to exist is determined.

Firstly, system (3) has five equilibria p 1 ¼ ð0:8,0:8,À1:6,1:6Þ, p 2 ¼ ð 0:8 3 , 0:8 3 ,À 1:6 3 , 1:6 3 Þ, p 3 ¼ ð0; 0,0; 0Þ, p 4 ¼ ðÀ 0:8 3 ,À 0:8 3 , 1:6 3 ,À 1:6 3 Þ, and p 5 ¼ ðÀ0:8,À0:8,1:6,À1:6Þ. It is not difficult to find that the Jacobian matrix of system (3) at equilibria p 1 ,p 3 ,p 5 is 4) for p¼ 2.27, (a)

The Jacobian matrix at equilibria p 2 ,p 4 is whose eigenvalues are l 1 ¼ 98:9912, l 2 ¼ 1:5209, l 3;4 ¼ 0:74397 5:2291i. Similar to its integer-order counterpart, a necessary condition for a fractional-order system to exhibit chaotic attractor is the instability of the equilibrium points. By Lemma 1, system (3) will exhibit regular behavior if condition (1) is satisfied. That is to say, the lowest order a for a fractional-order system to exhibit chaotic attractor must satisfy a4ð2=pÞmin i 9argðl i Þ9.

From the above calculations, we can obtain min i 9argðl i Þ9 ¼ 1:4295. Thus, for system (3), the lowest order for chaos to exist is a4 2 p min i 9argðl i Þ9 % 0:91: That is, system (3) does not show chaotic behavior when ao0:91. This conclusion is verified by numerical simulations. The Adams-Bashforth-Moulton method [26] for solving fractional order differential equations is employed in the simulations. The phase portraits of system (3) are shown in Fig. 2 with the initial values ð0:1,0:1,À0:1,0:1Þ T and a ¼ 0:90. Fig. 2 indicates that system (3) will exhibit periodic motion when a ¼ 0:90. When a ¼ 0:92, the four Lyapunov exponents are calculated as LE1 ¼ 0:1340,LE2 ¼ 0:0082,LE3 ¼ À0:2336,LE4 ¼ À74:4010, respectively. The Lyapunov exponents are calculated by orthogonal matrix method [27] with time length 1000 and time step size 0.01. It is reasonable to consider the second larger Lyapunov exponent 0.0082 as zero, and therefore system (3) is chaotic when a ¼ 0:92. Fig. 3 shows the chaotic attractor in system (3) when a ¼ 0:92 with the same initial values as Fig. 2.

div.head: Bifurcation analysis
div.p: In this section, the dynamics of system (3) is discussed in detail with the variation of some specified parameter. Fix the order of system (3) as a ¼ 0:97, which is greater than the lowest order 0.91. Since the order a is relatively large, then system (3) is more likely to exhibit different dynamical behaviors when some specified parameter of the system varies.

When a ¼ 0:97, the four Lyapunov exponents are calculated as LE1 ¼ 0:1938, LE2 ¼ 0:1180, LE3 ¼ À0:0061, LE4 ¼ À96:8963. In this section, the Lyapunov exponents are calculated by orthogonal matrix method with time length 1000 and time step size 0.05. Two positive Lyapunov exponents indicate that there exists a hyperchaos in system (3). When a ¼ 0:97, the phase portraits of system (3) are shown in Fig. 4 with the initial values ð0:1,0:1,À0:1,0:1Þ T . Meanwhile, the Poincare ´sections of system (3) are calculated for a ¼ 0:97 as shown in Fig. 5, which confirms the existence of the hyperchaotic attractor. The sections are taken as x 3 ¼ 0,x 3 ¼ 7 1: 6 3 respectively.
In what follows, we fix a ¼ 0:97 and let a specified parameter vary over a certain range to discuss the complex dynamics of system (3). In this case, the system can be described as
div.formula: D a t x 1 ðtÞ ¼ Àx 3 Àx 4 ,
D a t x 4 ðtÞ ¼ 100ðx 1 Àgðx 4 ÞÞ,ð4Þ
div.p: where
div.formula: gðx 4 Þ ¼ x 4 Àð9x 4 À0:49À9x 4 À0:89À9x 4 þ 0:49 þ 9x 4 þ0:89Þ:
div.p: The Lyapunov exponent spectrum is calculated with respect to p and p varies from 1.5 to 2.7 with step 0.01. The orthogonal matrix method is applied to calculate the Lyapunov exponent spectrum with time length 300 and time step size 0.01. Since the fourth Lyapunov exponent is always negative, we merely draw a spectrum of the first three Lyapunov exponents, as shown in Fig. 6. It can be found from Fig. 6 that hyperchaotic attractor does exist for a wide range of parameter p. The bifurcation diagram of x 1 with respect to p is shown in Fig. 7, and similarly p varies from 1.5 to 2.7 with step size 0.001. It can be found that the bifurcation diagram is coincident with the Lyapunov exponent spectrum. From Figs. 6 and7, it can be seen that system (4) exhibits chaos when p ranges from about 1.5 to 1.85, and system (4) exhibits hyperchaos when p ranges from about 1.86 to 2.15. In fact, Fig. 4 just shows the case of p ¼2. When p ranges from 2.25 to 2.28, system (4) is periodic. In particular, when p ¼2.27, since the largest Lyapunov exponent is 0.0092, we can consider it as zero, and hence system (4) is periodic. The phase portraits for p ¼2.27 are depicted in Fig. 8 with the initial values ð0:1,0:1,À0:1,0:1Þ T and the Poincare ´sections, as shown in Fig. 9, confirm that system (4) will exhibit periodic motions when p ¼2.27.

When p ¼1.8, the first three Lyapunov exponents are calculated as LE1 ¼ 0:1964, LE2 ¼ 0:0037, LE3 ¼ À0:1388. It is reasonable to consider the second larger Lyapunov exponent 0.0037 as zero, and thus system (4) is chaotic. The phase portraits for p ¼1.8 are illustrated in Fig. 10 with the initial values ð0:1,0:1,À0:1,0:1Þ T . The Poincare ´sections of system (4) for p ¼1.8 are shown as in Fig. 11.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: In this paper, a fractional-order four-cell CNN is proposed and the complex dynamics of such a system is detailedly investigated by numerical simulations. It can be found that the newly proposed fractional-order CNN does exhibit quite rich dynamical behaviors, including periodic, chaotic and hyperchaotic motions, which are verified by virtue of Lyapunov exponents, Poincare śections, bifurcation diagram, and phase portraits. Furthermore, hyperchaotic phenomena exist within a wide range of parameter value. The novel fractional-order hyperchaos provides a new hyperchaos generator and can be applied in many engineering applications, especially in the secure communication.

He has been a postgraduate in Control Theory and Control Engineering at the College of Information and Electrical Engineering, Shandong University of Science and Technology since 2010. His current research interest covers neural networks, chaos control and synchronization, and fractional-order nonlinear systems
